newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong gold ends up on shortcovering.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong gold ends up on shortcovering.

text.p: Gold ended a shade higher on Tuesday against New York's Monday close after a session of two-way trade, dealers said.
"The price of gold dipping below US$375 levels triggered some early follow-through selling interest," said a dealer at a major bank.
"The gold market dropped even further on sales triggered by bearish sentiment due to a continuing rise in the U.S. and Hong Kong stock market," another bullion dealer said.
But downward pressure from sales also sparked a shortcovering spree, which pushed the market back to near New York's closing levels.
The market held at $374 per ounce, dealers said.
Physical gold demand emerged slightly but buyers remained wary and business was limited to dribs and drabs, gold traders said.
Tael gold traded at a healthy premium to spot gold with tael gold's dollar equivalent at $375.00/50 per ounce.
This made arbitrage between spot gold and tael gold attractive, with players taking short positions on the Chinese Gold and Silver Exchange Society.
"People were selling taels and buying spot gold," a senior gold dealer said.
Bullion ended at US$374.40/90 an ounce against New York's US$374.35/85 close on Monday.
Local gold ended HK$6 lower at HK$3,457 a tael.
The carryover charge at the Chinese Gold and Silver Exchange Society dropped from nil to -3.
